position.marginalia_text: Corduba adolescentulus vtroq[ue] erat egregius: et arguta ratiocinatione pra[e] ca[e]teris: et multiplici artiu[m] instructu

illi Fortius. Fortio Ramus: Ramo Freigius: Freigio Gregoris: Gregorio = [[F7r]:= Caius Julius Guercentius, qui sexcentis audientibus profitebatur, se quindecim diebus mathematicas scientias perfecta explicatione pra[e]lecturum: Geometr. Arithm. Astron. ( Egregius mea memoria professor, et discursor in pla[e]risq[ue] admirabilis: idemq[ue] ) imberbis adolescens, et pra[e]lector gladiatus. Post triduu[m], à Lauherno in philosophia; à Brouno in Mathematicis lacessitus: magis ( speciosè, quàm energeticè. Lauhernu[m], impudentem scurram, et egregium nebulonem sa[e]pè appellabat. Fugit metus causâ.]

marginalia.translation: A very young man in Cordoba was excellent in both disciplines; and with clever reasoning, he was beyond the other men; and instructed by various men of the arts, he was above all men. Fortius was next to him, and Ramus next Fortius. Next to Ramus was Freigius, and next to Freigius Gregoire. Next to Gregoire [[F7r]: Caius Julius Guercentius, who declared to six hundred listeners, that he was going to give a complete explanation of the mathematical sciences in just fifteen days, including geometry, arithmetic, and astronomy. In my memory, he is an illustrious professor, and a wondrous discourser on many subjects; at the same time, he was a beardless youth and an armed lecturer. After three days, he was provoked by Laugherne in philosophy and by Brown in mathematics, however they were more showy than effective. He frequently called Laugherne an impudent dandy and a singular scoundrel, who then fled in fear.]

position.marginalia_text: doni significatiuivi: comè Amore dipinto con vn fiore in vna mano, et vn pesce nell'altra
che gli signoreggia la terra, e 'l mare.

marginalia.translation: Meaningful gifts, such as Love painted with a flower in hand and a fish in the other, which means that he rules over land and sea. In Guazzo's fourth book.

position.marginalia_text: summèq[ue] pragmaticarum. Pulchrum laudo: non probo vanum.

marginalia.translation: Many academics today want to be like Lucian's rhetoricians, Turnebus' artists, philosophers of the court, or professors of Agrippa's sciences; particularly and especially concerning deceits, useful matters, noble things, and, most of all, pragmatic activities. I praise the beautiful man, but I do not approve the vain one.
Always focused on the thing at hand, as a tempest.

position.marginalia_text: Pra[e]sentior, et viuidior: argutior, et amabilior: quisquis maximè.
Mie mirrour of pollicie, Gandino. Mie pha[e]nix of singularitie, Apollonio.
